content: Sweden Legalizes Same-Sex Marriage Sweden became the seventh country in the world to legalize same-sex marriage nationwide Sweden became the seventh country in the world to legalize same-sex marriage nationwide after a six-hour debate on Wednesday among parliament members. All but one of the seven parties in the parliament, ruled by a center-right coalition, backed the legislation, which garnered a 261 to 22 vote, and 16 abstentions, according to the Associated Press. Gender-neutral marriage licenses will begin to be issued starting May 1, replacing a civil union option that has been offered since 1995. Religious institutions will not be compelled to perform ceremonies for gay and lesbian couples. A majority of bishops in the Church of Sweden said that churches should not be allowed the task of handling legal registrations of marriages. The Netherlands, Norway, Belgium, Spain, Canada, and South Africa already allow same-sex marriage. The Advocate >http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid77092.asp Sweden is one of the most civilized countries in the world.

content: quote: Agreed. The manner in which differences are resolved in a constitutional democracy like our's....is to submit the issue to a vote. If the result is unpopular with some, they are free to seek legal challenge in our court system. Congress can do that for us, they are democratically elected for that purpose. As is the POUS, thus he can, in some cases, issue an Executive order... and then there are the Court. So, a vote of the population is unnecessary and not necessarily an adequate reflection of the Constitution (California's latest "election" about same-sex marriage vs. Iowa's more constitutional rational, for example.) The Constitution is the factor more so than the people, as a general rule. So, I favor the reason applied in the Iowa case over the vote of the people in California. Secular equality and right to peruse happiness. DA/DT infringes on that ideal, even in the military.

Congress can do that for us, they are democratically elected for that purpose. As is the POUS, thus he can, in some cases, issue an Executive order... and then there are the Court. So, a vote of the population is unnecessary and not necessarily an adequate reflection of the Constitution (California's latest "election" about same-sex marriage vs. Iowa's more constitutional rational, for example.) The Constitution is the factor more so than the people, as a general rule. So, I favor the reason applied in the Iowa case over the vote of the people in California. Secular equality and right to peruse happiness. DA/DT infringes on that ideal, even in the military.
